Question Text: When APs are placed at different geographic locations, they can all be interconnected by a switched infrastructure. The 802.11 standard calls this an extended service set (ESS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. When access points (APs) are located at different physical locations, they can be interconnected using a switched infrastructure to create an extended service set (ESS). An ESS allows wireless clients to roam seamlessly between the APs while maintaining their network connection.
URLs: ['CCNA Wireless 200-355 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 1: Introduction to Wireless Networking Concepts', 'IEEE 802.11 Wireless LAN Standard']

Question Text: A lightweight access point in which one of the following architectures participate?
Choices:
a. Light-MAC
b. Tunnel-MAC
c. Big-MAC
d. Split-MAC
LLM Explanation: In a split-MAC architecture, the access point is divided into two parts: the radio and baseband functions remain in the access point (the 'light' part), while the management functions are handled by a central controller. This allows for a more cost-effective and manageable wireless network deployment.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/what-is-split-mac-architecture.html']

Question Text: Which of the following controller ports is used to connect to a peer controller for high availability (HA) operation?
Choices:
a. Service port
b. Distribution system port
c. Redundancy port
d. Console port
LLM Explanation: The redundancy port on a wireless LAN controller is used to connect to a peer controller for high availability (HA) operation. This dedicated port allows the active and standby controllers to synchronize their configuration and state information, enabling seamless failover if the active controller goes down.
URLs: ['Cisco Wireless LAN Controller Configuration Guide, Release 8.0 - Configuring High Availability: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-0/configuration-guide/b_cg80/b_cg80_chapter_01101.html', 'CCNA Wireless 200-355 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 6: Understanding Wireless LAN Controllers - High Availability: https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2473590&seqNum=6']

Question Text: Which of the following wireless security tools is used to protect the integrity of data in a wireless frame?
Choices:
a. MIC
b. WIPS
c. WEP
d. EAP
LLM Explanation: MIC (Message Integrity Check) is a wireless security tool used to protect the integrity of data in a wireless frame. It is a checksum calculated over the data payload and header fields of a wireless frame, ensuring that the data has not been altered in transit.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 26: Securing Wireless Networks)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless-mobility/wireless-lan-wlan/68005-wlan-security.html']

Question Text: Wi-Fi is based on ________________ IEEE standards.
LLM Explanation: Wi-Fi is based on the IEEE 802.11 standards. The 802.11 standards define the specifications for wireless local area networks (WLANs) operating in the 2.4 GHz, 5 GHz, and 6 GHz frequency bands. The other options, 802.2, 802.1, and 802.12, are not related to Wi-Fi standards.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11 Wireless Local Area Networks: https://www.ieee802.org/11/', 'Wi-Fi Alliance: https://www.wi-fi.org/discover-wi-fi/wi-fi-standards', 'Cisco Networking Academy: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 26: Wireless LANs']

Question Text: Which of the following bridges can be used to provide wireless connectivity to a non-wireless device?
Choices:
a. Wireless repeater
b. Workgroup bridge
c. Transparent bridge
d. Adaptive bridge
LLM Explanation: A workgroup bridge is used to provide wireless connectivity to devices that do not have built-in wireless capabilities. It connects to the wired Ethernet port of a device and allows it to communicate wirelessly with an access point or wireless router.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/workgroup-bridges/index.html']

Question Text: Which controller interface type maps a WLAN to a VLAN?
Choices:
a. Management interface
b. Redundancy management
c. Virtual interface
d. Service port interface
e. Dynamic interface
LLM Explanation: A dynamic interface on a wireless LAN controller maps a WLAN to a VLAN, allowing the WLAN to be associated with a specific VLAN for traffic segmentation and policy application. The other interfaces mentioned serve different purposes: the management interface is for out-of-band management, redundancy management is for high availability between controllers, the virtual interface is the default gateway for wireless clients, and the service port is for out-of-band management on some controller models.
URLs: ['Cisco Wireless LAN Controller Configuration Guide, Release 8.0 - Configuring Ports and Interfaces: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-0/configuration-guide/b_cg80/b_cg80_chapter_01001.html', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, Chapter 26: Securing Wireless Networks']

Question Text: Which is the most preferred and secure way of connecting to a WLC GUI to configure a new WLAN?
Choices:
a. SSH
b. HTTP
c. HTTPS
d. FTP
e. None of the above
LLM Explanation: HTTPS is the most preferred and secure way to connect to a Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) GUI for configuring a new WLAN. HTTPS provides encryption for the communication between the client and the WLC, ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of the configuration data. While SSH is secure, it is typically used for command-line access rather than GUI configuration. HTTP, FTP, and other unencrypted protocols are not recommended due to their lack of security.
URLs: ['Cisco Wireless LAN Controller Configuration Guide, Release 8.10 - Configuring Security Solutions: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-10/config-guide/b_cg810/configuring_security_solutions.html', 'CCNA Wireless 200-355 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 6: Accessing the WLC, Page 196-197, ISBN: 978-1-58720-690-1']

Question Text: The maximum configurable number of WLANs on a controller is __________________.
LLM Explanation: The maximum configurable number of WLANs on a Cisco wireless LAN controller is 512. This allows for a large number of separate wireless networks to be configured and managed by a single controller device.
URLs: ['Cisco Wireless LAN Controller Configuration Guide, Release 8.10 - https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-10/config-guide/b_cg810/b_cg810_chapter_01001.html']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.11 Wi-Fi standards use the 5 GHz band? (Choose all that apply)
LLM Explanation: The IEEE 802.11 Wi-Fi standards that use the 5 GHz band are:- 802.11a: This was the first Wi-Fi standard to use the 5 GHz band, providing data rates up to 54 Mbps.  - 802.11n: Introduced MIMO technology and operates on both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands, offering data rates up to 600 Mbps.- 802.11ac: Operates exclusively on the 5 GHz band, supporting data rates up to 6.9 Gbps using wider channels and higher-order modulation.- 802.11ax (Wi-Fi 6): The latest standard, operating on both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands, with improved efficiency and data rates up to 9.6 Gbps.The original 802.11, 802.11b, and 802.11g standards only use the 2.4 GHz band.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11 Wireless Local Area Networks: The Working Group for WLAN Standards. (n.d.). Retrieved from https://www.ieee802.org/11/', 'Cisco. (2020). 802.11 Wireless Standards. Retrieved from https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/802-11-wireless-standards.html', "Gast, M. (2013). 802.11ac: A Survival Guide. O'Reilly Media."]

Question Text: Wi-Fi commonly uses the 2.5GHz and __________________ GHz bands.
LLM Explanation: Wi-Fi commonly uses the 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequency bands. The 2.4GHz band is more widely supported by devices but is more prone to interference, while the 5GHz band offers faster speeds and less interference but has shorter range.

Question Text: Choose the term that best describes a Cisco wireless access point that operates in a standalone, independent manner.
Choices:
a. Standalone Access point (AP)
b. Autonomous Access Point (AP)
c. Independent Access Point (AP)
d. Cisco Access Point (AP)
LLM Explanation: An autonomous access point (AP) is a Cisco wireless access point that operates independently in a standalone manner without requiring a wireless LAN controller (WLC). It has all the intelligence built into the AP itself to handle management, configuration, and control functions. Autonomous APs are suitable for small deployments where centralized management is not required.
URLs: ['Cisco Press CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 29: Wireless Architectures', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/access_point/15-3-3/configuration/guide/cg15-3-3/cg15-3-3-chap1-overview.html']

Question Text: You are creating a new WLAN with the controller GUI, which of the following parameters are necessary? (Choose two)
Choices:
a. VLAN number
b. SSID
c. Interface
d. BSSID
e. IP subnet
LLM Explanation: When creating a new WLAN using the controller GUI, the two necessary parameters are the VLAN number and SSID. The VLAN number identifies the virtual LAN to which the WLAN should be mapped, allowing for logical separation of wireless traffic. The SSID (Service Set Identifier) is the name of the wireless network that clients will see and use to connect. The interface, BSSID (Basic Service Set Identifier), and IP subnet are not required parameters when initially setting up a WLAN on the controller.
URLs: ['Cisco Wireless LAN Controller Configuration Guide, Release 8.0 - Configuring WLANs (https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-0/configuration-guide/b_cg80/b_cg80_chapter_01000.html)', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 29: Securing Wireless Networks']

Question Text: Which one of the following is a wireless encryption method that is not recommended for use due to vulnerability issues?
Choices:
a. Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)
b. Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA)
c. Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP)
d. Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP)
LLM Explanation: Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) is a wireless encryption method that is not recommended for use due to known vulnerabilities. WEP has several security flaws that make it relatively easy to crack, such as weak initialization vectors (IVs) and the lack of a key management system. Attackers can collect enough data packets to crack the encryption key and gain unauthorized access to the wireless network. The other options, AES, WPA, and EAP, are more secure alternatives for wireless encryption and authentication.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Cisco Press, 2020', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless-mobility/wlan-security/68439-wep-wireless-security.html', 'https://www.networkworld.com/article/2278206/why-you-shouldn-t-be-using-wep-on-your-wi-fi.html']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.11 Wi-Fi standards use the 2.4 GHz band? (Choose all that apply)
LLM Explanation: The IEEE 802.11 Wi-Fi standards that use the 2.4 GHz band are:- 802.11: The original Wi-Fi standard, supports data rates up to 2 Mbps.- 802.11b: Supports data rates up to 11 Mbps.- 802.11g: Supports data rates up to 54 Mbps. - 802.11n: Supports both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands, with data rates up to 600 Mbps.- 802.11ax (Wi-Fi 6): The latest standard, supports both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands, with data rates up to 9.6 Gbps.802.11a and 802.11ac standards only use the 5 GHz band.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11 Wireless Local Area Networks: The Working Group for WLAN Standards. (n.d.). Retrieved from https://www.ieee802.org/11/', 'Cisco. (2020). Wireless Standards Explained. Retrieved from https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/wireless-standards.html']
